statement.p:
Determine whether the following statements are true or false and provide a justification of your response.
Every stochastic matrix has a steady-state vector.
If A is a stochastic matrix, then any Markov chain defined by A converges to a steady-state vector.
If A is a stochastic matrix, then \lambda=1 is an eigenvalue and all the other eigenvalues satisfy |\lambda| \lt 1.
A positive stochastic matrix has a unique steady-state vector.
If A is an invertible stochastic matrix, then so is A^{-1}.

li.p: True. Every stochastic matrix has an eigenvalue \lambda_1=1, and we can find a steady-state vector inside the eigenspace E_1.

False. We have seen examples, such as A=\mattwo0110, for which this is not true. We need to know that A is a positive matrix so that the Perron-Frobenius theorem applies if we want to reach this conclusion.
False. Again, we can only guarantee this if the matrix is positive so that the Perron-Frobenius theorem applies.
True. This follows from the Perron-Frobenius theorem.

False. If A is an invertible stochastic matrix, the eigenvalues of A must satisfy 0\lt |\lambda_j| \leq 1. The eigenvalues of A^{-1} are \frac1{\lambda_j}, which satisfy 1\leq \left|\frac1{\lambda_j}\right| so A^{-1} is most likely not stochastic.
True
False
False
True

statement.p:
Explain your responses to the following.
Why does Google use a Markov chain to compute the PageRank vector?
Describe two problems that can happen when Google constructs a Markov chain using the Google matrix G.
Describe how these problems are consistent with the Perron-Frobenius theorem.
Describe why the Perron-Frobenius theorem suggests creating a Markov chain using the modified Google matrix G' = \alpha G + (1-\alpha)H_n.

li.p: The modified Google matrix G' is huge, roughly 30 trillion \times 30 trillion, so it is not computationally feasible to compute the steady-state vector by finding a basis for \nul(G'-I).

It may happen that a Markov chain does not converge. We saw this with the cyclic web where a Markov chain just moved PageRank from one page to the next around a loop. Also, it may happen that a Markov chain converges to a probability vector with some zero entries. This happens when PageRank drains out of one part of the web.
In both of these situations, the Google matrix is not positive so the Perron-Frobenius theorem does not apply.
When we create G' in this way, we are guaranteed of having a positive stochastic matrix because all the entries of G' are positive.

statement.p:
Suppose that A is a stochastic matrix and that \xvec is a probability vector. We would like to explain why the product A\xvec is a probability vector.
Explain why \xvec=\threevec{0.4}{0.5}{0.1} is a probability vector and then find the product S\xvec.
More generally, if \xvec is any probability vector, what is the product S\xvec?
If A is a stochastic matrix, explain why SA=S.
Explain why A\xvec is a probability vector by considering the product SA\xvec.

li.p: Since the components of \xvec are nonnegative and add to 1, \xvec is a probability vector. We see that S\xvec=[1].
Multiplying any vector \xvec by S just adds the components of \xvec. Therefore, if \xvec is a probability vector, S\xvec=[1].
Because the columns of A add to 1, we see that S multiplying any column of A gives 1. Consequently, the entries in SA are the sums of the columns of A, which are all 1. This gives SA=S.

Because all the entries in both A and \xvec are nonnegative, it follows that the components of A\xvec are nonnegative. Then we have S(A\xvec)=(SA)\xvec = S\xvec = [1], which shows that the components of \xvec add to 1. Therefore, \xvec is a probability vector.
S\xvec=[1].
If \xvec is a probability vector, S\xvec=[1].
The entries in SA are the sums of the columns of A, which are all 1.

statement.p:
Using the results of the previous exercise, we would like to explain why A^2 is a stochastic matrix if A is stochastic.
Suppose that A and B are stochastic matrices. Explain why the product AB is a stochastic matrix by considering the product SAB.
Explain why A^2 is a stochastic matrix.
How do the steady-state vectors of A^2 compare to the steady-state vectors of A?

li.p: If both A and B are stochastic, all the entries of both A and B are nonnegative. Therefore, the entries of AB are also nonnegative. In addition, we have S(AB) = (SA)B = SB = S, which shows that AB is stochastic.
This follows from the previous part, which shows that the product of two stochastic matrices is stochastic.
If \qvec is a steady-state vector for A, it will be a steady-state vector for A^2 as well because A^2\qvec = A\qvec=\qvec.

However, it is possible that there are steady-state vectors of A^2 that are not steady-state vectors of A. If the eigenvalues of A are \lambda_j, remember that the eigenvalues of A^2 are \lambda_j^2. Therefore, A^2 can have more steady-state vectors if \lambda_j=-1 is an eigenvalue of A, which leads to \lambda_j^2=1. For instance, A=\mattwo0110 has a unique steady-state vector \twovec{\frac12}{\frac12} whereas every probability vector \twovec{p}{1-p} is a steady-state vector for A^2=\mattwo1001.
This follows from the previous part.
A steady-state vector for A is a steady-state vector for A^2 but a steady-state vector for A^2 is not necessarily a steady-state vector for A.

statement.p:
We saw a couple of model Internets in which a Markov chain defined by the Google matrix G did not converge to an appropriate PageRank vector. For this reason, Google defines the matrix
H_n = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \frac1n \amp \frac1n \amp \ldots \amp \frac1n \\ \frac1n \amp \frac1n \amp \ldots \amp \frac1n \\ \vdots \amp \vdots \amp \ddots \amp \vdots \\ \frac1n \amp \frac1n \amp \ldots \amp \frac1n \\ \end{array}\right] , where n is the number of web pages, and constructs a Markov chain from the modified Google matrix G' = \alpha G + (1-\alpha)H_n. Since G' is positive, the Markov chain is guaranteed to converge to a unique steady-state vector.

We said that Google chooses \alpha = 0.85 so we might wonder why this is a good choice. We will explore the role of \alpha in this exercise. Let's consider the model Internet described in and construct the Google matrix G. In the Sage cell below, you can enter the matrix G and choose a value for \alpha.
def modified_markov_chain(A, x0, N): r = A.nrows() A = alpha*A + (1-alpha)*matrix(r,r,[1.0/r]*(r*r)) for i in range(N): x0 = A*x0 print (x0.numerical_approx(digits=3)) ## Define the matrix original Google matrix G and choose alpha. ## The function above finds the modified Google matrix ## and resulting Markov chain alpha = 0 G = x0 = vector([1,0,0,0,0]) modified_markov_chain(G, x0, 20)
Let's begin with \alpha=0. With this choice, what is the matrix G'=\alpha G + (1-\alpha)H_n? Construct a Markov chain using the Sage cell above. How many steps are required for the Markov chain to converge to the accuracy with which the vectors \xvec_k are displayed?
Now choose \alpha=0.25. How many steps are required for the Markov chain to converge to the accuracy at which the vectors \xvec_k are displayed?
Repeat this experiment with \alpha = 0.5 and \alpha=0.75.
What happens if \alpha = 1?

This experiment gives some insight into the choice of \alpha. The smaller \alpha is, the faster the Markov chain converges. This is important; since the matrix G' that Google works with is so large, we would like to minimize the number of terms in the Markov chain that we need to compute. On the other hand, as we lower \alpha, the matrix G' = \alpha G + (1-\alpha)H_n begins to resemble H_n more and G less. The value \alpha=0.85 is chosen so that the matrix G' sufficiently resembles G while having the Markov chain converge in a reasonable amount of steps.

solution.p:
Remember that the steady-state vector for G' is \qvec=\left[\begin{array}{c} \frac15 \\ \frac15 \\ \frac15 \\ \frac15 \\ \frac15 \\ \end{array}\right].
If \alpha = 0, then G'=H_n and we see that any Markov chain converges to \qvec in one term. That is, \xvec_1=\qvec.
After six terms, we have \xvec_6=\qvec to three digits.
With \alpha = 0.5, it is not until \xvec_{11}=\qvec to three digits. With \alpha=0.75, it is not until \xvec_{26}.
With \alpha=1, we have G'=G so the Markov chain will never converge.

statement.p: This exercise will analyze the board game Chutes and Ladders, or at least a simplified version of it.

sidebyside.p: The board for this game consists of 100 squares arranged in a 10\times10 grid and numbered 1 to 100. There are pairs of squares joined by a ladder and pairs joined by a chute. All players begin in square 1 and take turns rolling a die. On their turn, a player will move ahead the number of squares indicated on the die. If they arrive at a square at the bottom of a ladder, they move to the square at the top of the ladder. If they arrive at a square at the top of a chute, they move down to the square at the bottom of the chute. The winner is the first player to reach square 100.

image.shortdescription: The game board from Chutes and Ladders.

description.p: The game board from Chutes and Ladders. There is a 10\times10 grid of squares labelled from 1 to 100. The squares in the bottom row are labelled 1 to 10 from left to right. The squares in the second to the bottom row are labelled 11 to 20 from right to left so that square 11 is directly above square 10. In the third row from the bottom, squares are labelled 21 to 30 from left to right, and this pattern continues.

There are also a number of ladders that connect squares labelled by smaller numbers to squares labelled by larger numbers. There are also chutes, or slides, that connect squares labelled by larger numbers to squares labelled by smaller numbers.

li.p: We begin by playing a simpler version of this game with only eight squares laid out in a row as shown in and containing neither chutes nor ladders. Rather than a six-sided die, we will toss a coin and move ahead one or two squares depending on the result of the coin toss. If we are on square 7, we move ahead to square 8 regardless of the coin flip, and if we are on square 8, we will stay there forever.

statement.p: One can analyze the full version of Chutes and Ladders having 100 squares in the same way. Without any chutes or ladders, one finds that the average number of moves required to reach square 100 is 29.0. Once we add the chutes and ladders back in, the average number of moves required to reach square 100 is 27.1. This shows that the average number of moves does not change significantly when we add the chutes and ladders. There is, however, much more variation in the possibilities because it is possible to reach square 100 much more quickly and much more slowly.
